nodes.text: A simple, computationally convenient estimator (dynamic OLS/GLS) can consistently and efficiently estimate cointegrating vectors in systems with deterministic components and variables integrated of general orders, and can be used to draw inference (Wald tests) and study long-run economic relations such as U.S. Ml money demand

We develop two simple estimators of cointegrating vectors (dynamic OLS, DOLS, and dynamic GLS, DGLS) based on a two-sided triangular representation and motivated as Gaussian MLEs for that parameterization

Method: represent the system in a two-sided triangular form for I(d) variables, orthogonalize errors by projecting onto leads and lags, then estimate cointegrating coefficients by OLS with leads/lags (DOLS) or feasible GLS after spectral/AR correction (DGLS)

Theoretical result: under general conditions (Assumptions A-C, finite parameterization of lead/lag polynomials) the DOLS and DGLS estimators are asymptotically efficient, have mixed-normal limits for coefficient estimators, and Wald statistics for linear hypotheses are asymptotically chi-squared

Monte Carlo evidence: in finite samples DOLS and DGLS reduce bias relative to static OLS; performance depends on short-run dynamics and truncation of infinite lead/lag polynomials, with DOLS often performing best in designs calibrated to U.S. Ml dynamics
Application: estimate long-run nominal Ml demand in the U.S. (1900-1989) by cointegrating m - p with log income and an interest rate using DOLS/DGLS and other efficient estimators

Empirical result (full sample): using 1900-1989 annual data the estimated income elasticity is near one and the interest semielasticity near -0.10; DOLS 95% CIs are approximately (0.88, 1.06) for income and (-0.127, -0.075) for the interest semielasticity

Empirical result (postwar data): estimates based only on postwar data are unstable and imprecise because postwar series are dominated by a single low-frequency trend (income and interest rate growth with nearly constant real balances), so parameters are weakly identified and sampling uncertainty is large

Conclusion: evidence is consistent with a stable long-run Ml demand relation spanning 1900-1989 (supporting Lucas' suggestion), but postwar data alone provide little precise information on individual elasticities because of multicollinearity from dominant trends

Recommendation/claim: practitioners should consider multiple efficient estimators; in the Monte Carlo designs and empirical application DOLS with an autoregressive-based covariance estimator performed well and is recommended when short samples and strong low-frequency trends exist

Assumption: implementation requires knowledge or consistent estimation of orders of integration and which variables cointegrate (pretesting or theory); some lag/lead polynomials must be finitely parameterized or truncated carefully

Limitation: asymptotic approximations can be poor in small samples or when nuisance spectral parameters are estimated, leading to undercoverage of nominal confidence intervals and sensitivity of some estimators (e.g., Johansen MLE) to lag choices and sample endpoints

Claim: Wald tests based on the proposed estimators are asymptotically chi-squared for testing linear restrictions on cointegrating vectors, even when regressors include time polynomials or variables of differing integration orders
